sect1.title: Working with Smart Docs
sect1.para: Smart Docs represent the modular approach to documentation whose goal is producing sets of adaptable, solution-based, easy-to-find and reusable documents.
Smart Documentation consists of smaller information units with the following characteristics:

formalpara.title: Self-contained
formalpara.para: Each information unit stands for itself, including requirements, context, instructions and FAQs.

formalpara.title: Cover one distinct topic
formalpara.para: Rather than covering a complete technology or a set of problems, each information unit serves one distinct purpose. Five different types of information units are provided:

listitem.para: Assembly builds the actual article from the components listed below.
Task topics instruct the user how to perform certain tasks.
Concept topics explain underlying concepts to the users.
Reference topics inform the user about basic facts (settings, options, parameters, etc.).

Glue topics help navigate complex topics and provide links to related information (combine texts or structures that do not fit into any other category). Typical glue topics include For more information and What's next sections. Use glue topics to also add an additional layer of navigation to your article.

formalpara.title: Reused in different contexts
formalpara.para: Task, concept and reference information units can be reused in different context. Content units (articles) are built by bundling these into dedicated assembly files.

sect1.para: To create a Smart Docs project, use the templates for the assembly and its topical components that are provided in the Doc Modular repository at .

sect2.title: Using ITS tags with assemblies
sect2.para: Assembly files use ITS tags and attributes which flag whether the content of the tag should be translated or not. In the following example, the ITS attribute indicates that the content of the tag should not be translated. If the attribute is set to yes, translation is needed.
